can we get one more eyeball on #31666 ? lightlike dergoegge ?
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31666 | multi-peer orphan resolution followups by glozow 路 Pull Request #31666 路 bitcoin/bitcoin 路 GitHub
maybe even a pair of eyeballs
our translation service https://www.transifex.com has changed the owner -- https://xtm.cloud/blog/xtm-international-acquires-transifex/
instagibbs: started to look at it yesterday, will leave a review soon
lightlike: thank you so much
what's the latest on cmake flags for making sure things aren't optimized out?
thought I had it sorted but fuzz build is optimizing everything out with -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug
argh, nevermind, running wrong binary....

sipa: was discussing with instagibbs, we might want to still implement a count limit. with really small txns (say 300Wu), the upper bound on number of orphans really blows up when we move to wu limit. We could also include memusage of OrphanTx for accounting, but that still brings us to potentially thousands of txns per peer.
maybe something generous like 100 per peer, and not parameterizable?
166k orphans naively done, only slightly less with memory accounting
if you allow 40MWU
glozow: i see no problem with that
yeah was still getting in the 10ks with memusage
a natural choice would be 25 per inbound, and 250 per outbound (matching the ratio with the ancestor-set limits)
anything larger than 100 capped is still a superset し
(in the sense that both weight/count limits then imply one maximal ancestor set in-flight per inbound, and 10 ancestor sets in-flight per outbound)

right
the last transaction in the package never enters the orphanage

glozow: is there a super-linear complexity associated with more transactions in the orphanage?
or is it just that many tiny transactions have a high memory cost
I was concerned about super-linearity, since I got a sneak peek at the implementation
by "super-linear" i really mean O(n^2) or so; O(n log n) wouldn't be an issue
it was the "choosing next peer to un-announce" algorithm that was hitting O(n^2) IIRC
things can likely be recomputed better, it just wasnt doing that and I was worried about actually hitting a 29 release?
something originally engineered for 100 going to 166k, gave me pause
ok, in that case, a fixed per-peer limit may be more appropriate than one that scales with outbound vs inbound
> scales with outbound vs inbound
can you be pedantic here for clarity
my reasoning is that we're essentially ok with outbound peers taking 10x more resources (per peer) than inbound ones, because they're less likely to be under attacker control
"fixed per-peer limit " meaning not having differing reservations based on preferred-ness?

but if there are non-linear resource costs associated with the number of transactions involved, say O(n^2), then that really means that outbounds should only have a limit that's sqrt(10) times higher than that of inbound peers, not 10 times
actually, is this O(n^2) in function of the total number of transactions, or the number of transactions announced by a single peer?
gotta bounce, will be back later

sipa instagibbs: hm yeah, there are various places with looping... e.g. what happens if you have 100 inbounds and they each announce 10k of the same small transactions to you. it's going to take a long time to finally evict an orphan because you're removing them as announcers one by one
I'm now quite interested in the idea of having separate orphanages for inbounds and outbounds
glozow: is this with a global (weight) limit, or a per-peer weight limit (ignoring count limit for this)
sipa: this is with a per-peer weight limit
er wait, "this" = how we get the problem with looping a lot before we evict something?

glozow: if each of 100 inbounds announce the same 10k txs -- you add each tx to the orphan request tracker, prioritized randomly, hit the per-peer-limit as you're going, remove that peer's lowest priority tx, repeat? those should all be O(log(peers*peer_orphan_count_limit)) ? the peer_orphan_count_limit should presumably be lower than MAX_PEER_TX_ANNOUNCEMENTS=5000 since you need to keep the orphan
tx around, not just a txid
_aj_: are you thinking of the orphan request tracker TxRequestTracker?
glozow: yeah?
(In this situation we're remembering which invs correspond to which orphan txns so we can drop them right?)
ok so, we ended up dropping that, and just add the parent txids to normal `m_txrequest`
glozow: the parent txid or a pointer to an orphan tracker?
the parent txid
glozow: (32B for every non-orphan requested seems slightly lame)
what do you mean?
if you have tx O as an orphan, with missing parents P1 and P2, you tock P1{O} and P2{O} into m_txrequest or you stick O into m_txrequest?
tock? stick
we put P1 and P2 in m_txrequest
and don't remember that they are related to O
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/809d7e763cc9bdfff3288860a1c530460c76ffff/src/node/txdownloadman_impl.cpp#L403-L424
hmm, why did the orphan tx tracker get dropped? seems much more efficient to have it, than not?
